It is fine for those of us who have children. We should think of those who do not have children. They should not be put through unnecessary bureaucratic delays.

I am astounded at the attitude of Deputy Mitchell, in saying that it is all about bureaucracy. It is about ensuring that parents who wish to adopt children from abroad are suitable to do so. It is not solely about the parents but it must be in the best interests of the child. We must be in a position to assure any sending country that our procedures are rigorous, that we can stand over them and that these parents have an order of suitability to adopt.

That said, great improvements have been made in the system. The investment over the three years has totalled £1.5 million, half of which has gone to the eastern area. I recognise that there is a huge increase in the number of people who wish to adopt from abroad.
Deputy Mitchell's figures are quite wrong. Last year there were, in fact, 788 extra couples who applied to join, 370 of whom were in the east. Naturally it is my intention and my policy—

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: My figures are not wrong.

—to assure all of those people, of our assistance in their work by investment, by giving extra staff for the social workers who carry out those assessments. In 1998, in the east alone there were only 5.5 social workers doing this work but there are now 14 doing it. There is funding for 20, but it is difficult to get full-time, part-time or even sessional social workers to do the work.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: That is the problem.

We have gone as far as South Africa and Australia to recruit. We also have set in place new procedures, which means that the procedure is now standardised throughout the country, which can ensure that the system is more streamlined and that each social worker is able to take more cases. What we simply must do in all cases is to assure the sending country that the parents, whom we ratify as having an order of suitability to adopt, are suitable and that it would be in the best interests of the child that he or she would be placed in this home.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: The Minister says my figures are wrong. I said that in one health board area alone 100 parents applied in the first quarter last year. My figures are quite correct. I received my figures from people who are involved in this.

The Minister says we must be careful about how we go about this. I agree with all of that, but the problem is we do not have enough social workers. That is because the Minister of State is failing in her job. It is all right for those of us in this House who have children of our own, but to come in here and read out Civil Service bureaucratic replies of that kind affects the right of children to be adopted and the right of parents to adopt those children.
The time limit has expired.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: It is an outrage.
We must proceed to Question No. 22.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: The fact that there is a shortage of social workers is the Minister of State's problem. She should solve that problem.
We must proceed to the next Question.
The improvement, from 5.5 to 14 social workers, should be noted.
The Chair has called Question No. 22.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna–Questions (Resumed). - Hospital Services.

Qst.Quest: his views on the health board investigation on medical practice leading to a high level of caesarean hysterectomies in Our Lady of Lourdes Hospital, Drogheda, County Louth; the steps he is taking to deal with this issue and to ensure that women are protected from such practices in the future; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The matter raised by the Deputy is an important and sensitive one and is being handled accordingly by the North Eastern Health Board which has statutory responsibility for the management of services at the hospital to which she referred.
The North Eastern Health Board notified my Department immediately when this issue first came to light and I have been kept fully informed of developments since then.

MainHeading.P: The chief executive officer of the North Eastern Health Board took immediate steps to deal with the situation as soon as he became aware of it and the board initiated a review which was carried out by experts nominated by the Institute of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists. The report of the review group has been referred by the board to the Medical Council in the context of its statutory functions as set out in the Medical Practitioners Act, 1978.

I went to Drogheda last July and met many of the women involved and heard their experiences at first hand. The meeting was organised by Patient Focus. I had a further meeting with a group representing the women involved on Tuesday, 24 October 2000. I indicated at that meeting that I felt it would be better to await the outcome of the Medical Council's deliberations before deciding on any further action that might be required in this case. I intend to keep the matter under active review.

Speaker.P: Would the Minister accept that what we are talking about here is an extremely serious matter? The issue relates to what can only be described as systematic unnecessary mutilation of women of child-bearing age. There may be as many as 90 women who had this experience and certainly the practice went back at least 21 years. Would the Minister accept that while we all understand that the health board acted swiftly once it was notified, the reality is that this practice was continuing, in effect, practically on a daily basis and yet nobody blew the whistle until two young nurses could take it no longer? As the Minister responsible for the management and care of patients, surely his duty must be to ensure, first, that it will not happen again to any patient but, second, that the truth be told.

Would he accept that it is not solely the responsibility of the Medical Council? The Medical Council has statutory responsibility in terms of professional practice and it is proceeding on that basis relating to one professional, but we are talking about a hospital which failed its patients and about a system which destroyed the possibility for many women to bear more children.

It is an extremely serious situation. Surely the Minister would recognise that he must make a commitment now that the truth will be told, that there will be a tribunal of inquiry and that there will be an assessment carried out of the history of these women. As Minister for Health and Children, he also has a duty to set in place systems throughout the country to monitor and assess what consultants are doing. We can no longer accept that somehow a consultant cannot make a mistake, cannot become mentally ill, and cannot do things which are unacceptable and which are a danger to his patient in all cases. This has implications for the entire hospital system.
The Deputy should confine herself to questions.

I agree with the Deputy that this is a particularly serious issue and episode. As evidence of my earnestness in this matter and how seriously I regarded it, I took the step to go and meet the women concerned. Clearly the conclusions of the review group of a number of experts from the Institute of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists give even further rise for concern, namely that 46% of the hysterectomy cases were unacceptable, that a further 12% were doubtful, etc. It also concluded that the protocols and procedures within the hospital were not acceptable and were not on a par with what one would expect across the system, and that the level of interaction and intra-action between the maternity unit of that hospital at the time and the remainder of the hospital was very poor almost to the point of non-existence. Therefore I agree that there are a range of issues which relate to the hospital as well as to the particular individual.

I sought some indication from the Medical Council as to the time frame for its deliberations. My understanding was that it hoped to be in a position to conclude either around the end of February or later, but that is a matter for the Medical Council – we have no control over that.

I am not ruling out an inquiry. I do not want to prejudge the content of that inquiry or make remarks which might appear to prejudge it. I formed a judgment at the time that before I proceed further it seemed logical to wait for the deliberations of the Medical Council which could inform any further action to be taken on this issue.
I ask the Minister to outline his view. He must have some idea of what he intends to do following the completion of the Medical Council's work.

The Medical Council is assessing the fitness of one doctor. The Minister is responsible for the correct management of the hospitals. Surely he has a duty to outline how in intends to deal with the individual cases, even if it is only a general outline in terms of their needs. I appreciate that work has been done by the health board and everybody recognises that, but more must be done.
We must proceed to the next Question, Question No. 23.

I will revert to the Deputy on the matter. I would not rule out anything. I take the points she has made about the broader picture. The women concerned and those representing them have made that very point to me. Clearly what went on relates to more than one individual.
Obviously there is a process here. Clearly we want to establish what happened and the full truth across the hospital, and subsequently make sure lessons are learned for the future and that protocols—
We must proceed to Question No. 23.

Qst.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Qst.Quest: the way in which he will tackle the crisis now facing general practice.

Speaker.P: There is no crisis facing general practice. There is a need to address a number of serious infrastructural issues in general practice, including, its fragmented organisation, coupled with the growing volume and complexity of general practice work load, in order that its future development can be charted in a manner that maximises the contribution it can make to the overall health services.

This is all on the basis of a fundamental recognition that the health care system of the future will be characterised by greater integration and the maximisation of the contribution of component parts through better linkages, rising public expectations, increasing demands for additional health care services, especially of a screening or preventative type, and an increased focus on value for money from public expenditure. In that scenario, a more comprehensive and rationally developed general practice and primary care system should and can play a central role. To do so, it must be properly organised and resourced. It was in recognition of this that health board chief executive officers, with significant input from my Department, initiated a wide-ranging review of general practice.

The purpose of the review was to identify the measures necessary to meet the challenges posed if general practice were to be properly developed. That review has been completed and its findings are intended to serve as the basis for the future strategic development of general practice. I intend to obtain the agreement of Government to begin the process of moving forward in this area in a structured, logical manner and through a partnership process. An important aspect will be a wide-ranging consultative exercise with the representative bodies, especially the Irish Medical Organisation and the Irish College of General Practitioners which have produced a vision statement for the future. That jointly prepared document will feature as part of the consultative process referred to.

I look forward to a positive engagement with all concerned. Independently of the review, I am already addressing a number of issues of concern to general practitioners, their patients and the public, such as the provision of an appropriate out of hours general practitioner service. Pilot models are in place in two health board areas and funding will be made available this year to help all health boards develop out of hours GP services. After an evaluation, that process will continue. GPs will benefit in terms of workload commitments from these initiatives and I hope the positive support demonstrated by them for the out of hours projects will be manifest again in the broader strategic developments of the future.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna–Questions (Resumed). - Clinical Trials.

Qst.Quest: if, given his responses to previous parliamentary questions, he will clarify the number of clinical trials approved during the years 1960 to 1997, inclusive, on patients in psychiatric institutions; the names of the psychiatric institutions which carried out these trials; the number of patients involved in trials from 1960 to date; the procedure to obtain fully informed written consent from the patients; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.P: Up to 1987 there were no provisions for the statutory control of the conduct of clinical trials. Following the establishment of the National Drugs Advisory Board in 1966, a voluntary scheme was introduced with the agreement of the pharmaceutical industry and the medical and pharmaceutical professions. This scheme involved applications to the National Drugs Advisory Board and letters of no objection from the board in respect of the proposed trials. This informal scheme, which did not have a statutory backing, continued until the coming into force of the Control of Clinical Trials Act, 1987. On the basis of the annual reports published by the National Drugs Advisory Board, it has been estimated that approximately 2,022 letters of no objection were issued by the board for the period 1966 to 1988 in respect of applications to conduct clinical trials in this country.

The Control of Clinical Trials Act, 1987, imposed strict regulatory controls on the conducting of clinical trials in this country. Under this Act, which was amended in 1990, persons were required to make application to the Minister for Health and Children for permission to conduct clinical trials. These permissions were granted on the recommendation of the National Drugs Advisory Board. On the coming into force of the Irish Medicines Board Act, 1995, in January 1996, the Irish Medicines Board became the competent authority for the granting of such permissions. Approximately 1,900 permissions to conduct clinical trials, including trials in psychiatric institutions, were granted in the period 1989 to 1997.

MainHeading.P: Neither the National Drugs Advisory Board nor the Irish Medicines Board hold specific records in regard to psychiatric institutions. Accordingly, the number of trials carried out in psychiatric institutions is not available without retrieving all the files and going through them in considerable detail. However, the IMB is compiling data concerning clinical trials which were previously requested by the Deputy and these will be forwarded to the Deputy as soon as they are available. However, this procedure may not provide reliable or meaningful data as permissions may have been granted for trials which did not subsequently take place. This would also be the case where the number of participants involved in trials is concerned.

Additional InformationSince the coming into force of the Control of Clinical Trials Acts, 1987 to 1990, it is required that informed consent be obtained from all persons participating in the trials. For the purpose of ensuring the consent is valid, the Act requires that the consent must be given in writing and signed by the person who is to be the participant in the trial, the person consenting is capable of comprehending the nature, significance and scope of his consent, and the consent is obtained by or on behalf of the person conducting the trial.

The Act also requires that the person conducting a trial shall ensure that before giving his consent every person is made aware of the following matters: the objectives of the trial, the manner in which the substance or preparation is proposed to be administered, the risks and any discomfort involved in and the possible side effects of the trial, and whether the trial will involve the administration of placebos. The consent must be given in writing and signed by the person who is to be the participant.

On the Deputy's concern about psychiatric patients, I assure him that special provisions apply under the Act in the case of patients who, for practical and other reasons, are unable to give their written and signed consent. These provisions state that, where the patient is capable of comprehending the significance of his consent, he can give his consent to the doctor treating him for that illness in any other manner provided it is clearly given and in the presence of two witnesses who are present at the same time. In such cases the consent must be expressed in writing and be attested by the signature of the two witnesses. Where the patient is incapable of comprehending the significance of the consent to be given, he can participate in the trial only if written and signed consent to such participation is obtained from a person, or persons, who in the opinion of the ethics committee is or are competent to give such consent on his behalf. Such a person or persons must be independent of the person arranging to conduct the trial and of the doctor or dentist conducting the trial. It should be noted that in both these instances it is not permissible to conduct a clinical trial unless the substance or preparation under trial is to be administered for the purpose of saving the life of the patient, restoring his health, alleviating his condition or relieving his suffering. These safeguards were specifically provided to protect the interests of all patients, especially those with a mental illness.

The Deputy has raised this issue on a number of occasions and I have explained the rigorous process provided for obtaining consent under the Control of Clinical Trials Act. The Deputy should be aware that the raising of these matters has caused some concerns to former patients of psychiatric institutions and their relatives and I am anxious that any unnecessary concerns should be allayed. Therefore, if the Deputy has specific concerns about an individual case or individual areas, I would be grateful if he could provide me with the details so that any necessary investigation can be carried out without further delay.

Speaker.P: I thank the Minister for his limited reply. I have sought this information since early December last when he promised the various institutions would forward me the information. While clinical trials in orphanages in the 1950s are rightly being examined, I am surprised there is a lack of full information on trials which took place in psychiatric institutions. Does the Minister agree this indicates our attitude to psychiatric patients then and until now? Can he confirm for all trials dating back to the 1950s that fully informed written consent was obtained from each patient every time a clinical trial was conducted on him or her? Are those forms available for inspection? It is necessary that we allay the fears expressed about conducting clinical trials on psychiatric patients without their being fully informed of what was taking place. Would the Minister further agree that if fully informed consent was not received, that was akin to an abuse of the person's bodily integrity? It was physical abuse on the basis that clinical trials, by their nature, test the positive or negative effects of the drug.

I cannot confirm that because I have not read through all the files. The INB is currently checking its files. It is unreasonable to ask that I give a guarantee on that matter on the floor of the House today given that I have not read all the files.

If consent was not sought that would be in clear contravention of the Act. This House decided in 1987, in its wisdom, to put protocols and procedures for conducting clinical trials on a statutory footing. Obviously clinical trials in conventional medicine and mental illness treatment were envisaged at that time.

MainHeading.P: I listed, in my full answer, the protocols necessary before a person could take part in a clinical trial. The Deputy will be aware of them from previous replies. In other words, specific extra consent provisions were included in the Act to cover patients who, for practical and other reasons, were unable to give their written and signed consent. A patient who was capable of comprehending the significance of his consent could give his consent to a doctor treating him for that illness in any other manner provided such consent is clearly given in the presence of two witnesses. In such cases the consent must be expressed in writing and be attested by the signature of the two witnesses. Where the patient is incapable of comprehending the significance of the consent to be given, he can only participate in the trial if written and signed consent for such participation is obtained from a person or persons who, in the opinion of the ethics committee, is competent to give such consent on his behalf. Such a person or persons must be independent of the person arranging to conduct the trial and of the doctor or dentist conducting the trial.
The Act lays down very stringent controls in this area.

Speaker.P: The time for dealing with this question has concluded.

If Deputy Neville is aware of specific issues I would be only too glad to co-operate with him in seeking the truth regarding the conduct of particular trials. That would be in the interests of everybody involved in the provision of psychiatric services.

MainHeading.Title: Other Questions. - Psychiatric Services.

Speaker.P: The 1996 annual report from the national intellectual disability database indicated that of the 970 persons with an intellectual disability accommodated in psychiatric hospitals, 310 persons required alternative placements. The 1999 annual report indicated that of the 854 persons resident in psychiatric hospitals in April 1999, 493 needed to transfer to the intellectual disability services. The 1999 figures reflect both the ongoing transfer programme and the assessment of need review process which is part of the work associated with the intellectual disability database.

MainHeading.P: My Department is working with the health boards and the Eastern Regional Health Authority to provide alternative accommodation and services for this group and a programme of refurbishment in respect of accommodation which will continue to be used in the short to medium term. Twenty-nine persons from St. Finan's hospital, Killarney, recently moved into new purpose built accommodation and a further 87 persons in other health board areas will also move to similar facilities over the coming months. By the end of 2002, purpose built facilities for a further 87 persons, which are at an advanced stage of planning, will also have come on stream. This is over and above the provision which has and continues to be made for smaller groups of between four to six persons in community-based group homes.

My Department has requested an update on the numbers currently in psychiatric hospitals and the plans which the boards have in place to meet the needs which have been identified for this group. While this information has not yet been received from all of the health boards, it is clear that the numbers of persons with an intellectual disability in psychiatric hospitals is steadily declining and it is estimated that the current number will be between 650 and 680. I will inform the Deputy of the up to date position as soon as possible.

MainHeading.Title: Other Questions. - Hospital Services.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to a report from the Eastern Regional Health Authority showing that as much as 22% of theatre time in hospitals in that region is not being used, largely as a result of staff shortages; the steps being taken to ensure the optimum use of all theatre facilities; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.P: I am advised by the Eastern Regional Health Authority, ERHA, that the report referred to by the Deputy was completed in April 2000. Actual theatre utilisation was compared with that achievable if theatres were operated for five full days per week.

The main reason cited for lost theatre time was the shortage of trained personnel, particularly theatre nurses. Other factors which can give rise to under-utilisation of theatres include seasonal pressures which may lead to an increase in acute medical admissions at the expense of elective surgery and capacity constraints in other areas of the hospital, for example, ward accommodation and intensive care unit, ICU, facilities, leading to the unavailability of beds where patients can be transferred post – operatively. It should be recognised, however, that a number of hospitals have in recent years achieved significant productivity gains in the utilisation of available theatres.

MainHeading.P: The theatre utilisation survey formed an important element of the wider analysis undertaken by the ERHA of capacity constraints within acute hospitals. Underpinning this analysis has been a whole system approach which recognises the fact that service pressures in certain parts of the acute and non-acute sectors can give rise to difficulties in appropriately utilising existing capacity. This approach is essential in tar geting investment in order to achieve maximum patient benefit and efficiency throughout the continuum of health and social care. This system analysis has been set out by the ERHA in its recently completed bed capacity review. This review will inform the national review of bed capacity which will be completed shortly.

In co-operation with hospitals throughout the region the ERHA is addressing the management of how theatre time is planned, allocated and utilised by different specialities. The shortage of key hospital staff is being tackled on a number of fronts, including the operation, with good effect, of international recruitment campaigns. The ERHA is continuing to work closely with hospitals and other agencies to retain and recruit key staff. Recent figures available to my Department indicate that the shortages in Beaumont Hospital have reduced to ten from 110 in September 2000. Overall, 750 nurses have been recruited since the commencement of the international recruitment drive. I am informed by the ERHA that the wider factors impacting on theatre utilisation such as the management of acute medical admissions, early discharge planning and improved access to appropriate facilities are also being addressed within the region.

MainHeading.Title: Other Questions. - Nursing Homes.

Qst.hpid: Mr. S. Ryan Mr. S. Ryan
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to concerns expressed by consultants that greater use of step down facilities in nursing homes may result in elderly patients not receiving the appropriate level of medical care; the resources he will provide to ensure that all appropriate medical facilities, including rehabilitation facilities, are available in such locations; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.P: I presume the Deputy is referring to the winter initiative which was announced in October of last year. This initiative was designed to help alleviate anticipated service pressures and to maintain services to patients in the acute hospitals sector over the winter period. Under the initiative, I provided investment funding of £25 million which is being targeted at a number of areas, including the provision of aids and supports for use by older people and the recruitment of more than 40 additional hospital consultants to the hospital system. A key element of this initiative was the provision of funding to contract more than 500 places in private nursing homes. These beds are being contracted for the purpose of providing alternative complementary facilities for patients who have completed the acute phase of their treatment and care in a general hospital and who require short-term care in a more appropriate setting.

MainHeading.P: I emphasise that the continuing care needs of such patients discharged from a general hospital are determined by the appropriate consultant medical team. Consequently, there should be no question of people being discharged prematurely from acute hospital care without access to appropriate follow-up medical care provided, for example, through the general practitioner service. I recognise the need to further develop assess ment and rehabilitation services so that older people receive more effective treatment. More than £200 million has been made available to services for older people over the lifetime of the national development plan and health boards will develop such services as part of the plan. This issue is also being considered as part of the national review of bed capacity in the acute and sub-acute sectors.

In addition to the initiative I have outlined, the Government has provided considerable additional resources, both capital and revenue, for the development of services for older people. In the budget extra resources have been earmarked to continue this development. More than £10 million has been allocated for 2001 for community-based services, including improvements in the home help service and the further development of home rehabilitation services. This funding will be used to enhance the scope of the home help service to cover more people and to provide more hours for existing clients, to improve community support structures, specifically geared towards the support of older people in their homes as well as providing additional supports for carers. Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Rural Development (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.P: Confirmation by the authorities in Northern Ireland that they are investigating a suspected case of foot and mouth disease in the locality of Meigh, south Armagh, is of the utmost concern. The veterinary investigations being conducted by the Northern Ireland authorities centre on sheep which came from the Carlisle market in Britain. The outbreak in Devon has been attributed to sheep from this market.

The farm in Meigh has been under restriction for some time. Earlier today the Northern authorities decided to place an eight kilometre zone around the holding within which all movement of susceptible species is being prohibited. As a precautionary measure, they have also decided to slaughter the sheep in question, reflecting the approach being taken elsewhere in the European Union and following the advice of the standing veterinary committee yesterday to have similar type imported animals slaughtered.

The Border with Northern Ireland bisects the eight kilometre zone. Accordingly, and in order to complete the protective zone, my Department is putting in place a zone immediately south of the Border in north Louth into and out of which the movement of all animals will be prohibited. The area will then be put under veterinary scrutiny. The necessary order is being prepared and I am arranging for the assistance of the Garda and Army in ensuring that movement restrictions are fully effective.
The case under investigation in Meigh is not confirmed as a positive case – it is a suspect case – and these measures are, therefore, precautionary.

MainHeading.P: These are worrying developments. In the course of this morning my Department had a speedy review of the situation and carried out an investigation of existing controls. Arising from this, additional resources are to be deployed to control particular points of access and a number of other actions will also be taken. They reflect the suggestions made here yesterday and at the Oireachtas committee meeting where Deputies, including Deputy Dukes, made some suggestions. There was particular concern in regard to the movement of animals and movement of people and whether they could be minimised further. The additional measures are: prohibition on the movement within the country of all susceptible animals; the cancellation, by agreement with relevant bodies and otherwise, if necessary, of all hunting, fishing, hill walking activity which involves access to and passes through farmlands; an immediate call on all sporting bodies to postpone events, or where this is not possible to ensure that protective measures are in place so that vehicles and spectators undergo disinfection; a further public information campaign via the national media to support last weekend's information campaign.
The measures necessary to put the foregoing into effect including, where appropriate, the necessary legal instruments are being prepared for me.
We are into a new and deeply worrying phase of this issue and, just as I have done up to now, I am ruling nothing out when it comes to any further measures that may be necessary as matters unfold.

Speaker.P: I thank the Minister for outlining the further measures he proposes to take. He will understand I am not simply being curmudgeonly when I say I hope those measures are put fully into effect and that we do not see in them the kind of gaps in implementation that we have talked about in this House for the past week, because every day brings new indications of a vast difference between the intention and the practice on the measures. If it is the case that the main Dublin to Belfast road goes through the prohibition zone that surrounds the farm in question, as I am informed, will the Minister seek to put in place measures to divert traffic? I put it to him that it would be entirely undesirable for traffic to pass through that area given what we know about the way this disease can spread. Since the Minister has confirmed that the sheep on this farm were in the same location in Carlisle as sheep that finally turned up with the disease in Devon, has he any further information on any of the other sheep imported into this country between 1-20 February? The Minister of State, Deputy Davern, indicated yesterday that some 3,000 sheep been imported into this country came from Devon and what progress has been made in locating and slaughtering those sheep? Will the Minister see to it that information is made available to farmers on the symptoms of this disease? Specifically, will he cause to be put on the Department's website information on the symptoms which will be published and given wide publicity? The information contained on the British Ministry of Agriculture's website is clear, comprehensive and, as far as I know, reliable. Will the Minister agree it is extremely worrying to find, even as late as last night, that there is no clear description of the symptoms generally available to farmers and that even farm leaders are not in a position to give a clear description of these symptoms?

I thank Deputy Dukes for expressing his concern yesterday both here and at the Oireachtas committee meeting. I tried to ensure I took his views into account when drawing up the additional measures. In relation to gaps in the measures, I do not think it is possible to have totally watertight access points. We have put measures in place. We advertised them widely by putting advertisements in the newspapers, including clinical signs, over the weekend. I called on the general public to co-operate fully to seek to ensure this dreaded plague did not come into the country. I reiterate that call for people to co-operate.

In relation to sheep or any susceptible livestock that may have come into the country since 1 February, we have been in co-operation with the London and Belfast authorities who have a tracking system in place since then. We have established that at least three consignments of sheep came into the country, two to Wexford and one for slaughter in the west. The two in Wexford were put under surveillance straight away after it was established they came from Great Britain and will be slaughtered tomorrow as a precautionary measure. There are no suspects there and it is not a suspect case. The standing veterinary committee of the EU said yesterday if any animals were imported into member states from Britain that, as a precautionary measure, they should be slaughtered. That is being done.

In relation to the consignment of sheep that went for slaughter to the west, that plant was visited immediately after it had been established and the plant was disinfected and all the staff interviewed. Some 12 members of staff were part-time farmers or had association with farms. Those farms are restricted since it was established that sheep came in from outside the jurisdiction. We are continuing to do everything possible. Where there is scientific advice or where the standing veterinary committee of the EU say that measures should be taken, that is being done.
What about the main roads?
I was not sure if the main road went through the exclusion zone. It was only defined a couple of hours ago but I will establish that.

My information is that this farm is almost on the Border, as the Minister has indicated, that it joins the main road and that any eight kilometre exclusion or surveillance zone around the farm would cover the main road. That being the case, will the Minister ensure traffic is diverted because as long as we have a disease of this kind that can be carried in the air, it is clear there is a major risk of transmission via traffic going up and down the main road?

The information note provided to me says the zone south of the Border is being defined at present. This is being done in conjunction with the Garda. This will involve re-routing traffic from any of the roads that go through the exclusion zone. We have asked the Garda and the Army to assist in that re-routing of traffic.

We made a number of suggestions to the Minister's officials at the committee last evening, some of which have been taken on board. Will the Minister agree that the virus is very contagious, virulent, airborne and can be transmitted easily by way of transportation and humans? Given that people are a major source of transmission, is it time to consider restricting movement between susceptible zones?

In the event of a foot and mouth outbreak being identified here, what emergency or contingency plans are in place to deal it? Who would be responsible? That is why I called yesterday evening for a task force to be chaired by the Taoiseach. I am not happy that there is sufficient interdepartmental co-operation to deal with this issue. The Departments involved include Agriculture, Food and Rural Development, Justice, Equality and Law Reform, the Taoiseach and Finance. Does the Minister agree the Departments of Foreign Affairs and Tourism, Sport and Recreation should also be involved given that the angling season is now beginning and boats will be arriving in this country? I was contacted this morning by people who are involved in this business. Does the Minister agree the task force should have a wider remit than is currently the case?

Is there sufficient emergency legislation in place to deal with the crisis? If the movement of people has to be restricted, will that entail emergency legislation given the Supreme Court decision on the right to travel? Does the Minister agree the Taoiseach should lead by example and cancel his proposed visit to Wales tomorrow? I have advised my people not to travel home from England this weekend. We must lead by example. What level of co-operation is in place with the Minister for Agriculture in Northern Ireland? What has taken place to date to restrict the movement of susceptible animals onto the island and across the Border?

What measures are in place in the Minister's Department to ensure it does not become a risk area for the spread of foot and mouth disease? Is there a disinfectant system in place in Agriculture House which is just 300 metres from here?
No, I have been there.
I ask the question because I know of someone who was there. Numerous people are going to Agriculture House to fill in forms and so on.
The Deputy should confine his remarks to the question.

I am asking a question. Is there a disinfectant system in place in Agriculture House from where the example should emanate? Are there disinfectant stations in all Department of Agriculture, Food and Rural Development offices which are open to the public? Will the Minister encourage farmers to send in documentation and allow them additional time to do so rather than having them visit agricultural offices? Should the same apply to Teagasc offices? Are there sufficient reserves of disinfectant to increase the number of disinfectant units at points of entry to the country?

In the unfortunate event of a suspected case of foot and mouth disease in this jurisdiction, what steps are in place to ensure testing can take place without delay? Have we a laboratory capable of carrying out these tests or would the tests have to be carried out in Pirbright in England? If not, is the Minister prepared to invest in a well resourced epidemiological unit to test for diseases such as foot and mouth disease? Will the Minister guarantee that the current reserves of disinfectant are sufficient to ensure everyone entering the State from the UK can avail of same?

Deputy Penrose asked a number of questions. In relation to the movement of people, we have issued statements and directives and spoken with a number of relevant bodies who have promised to call off to the greatest extent possible various events. This applies to the IRFU in relation to the rugby match, horse race meetings, including point to point, and a range of greyhound race meetings. I have now included hunting, fishing, hill walking and so on. I have also asked Dúchas to cancel all trips to national parks where people might congregate in order to minimise the movement of people. I have asked people publicly to desist from making journeys outside the State, particularly to the UK, unless absolutely necessary. If they must travel, I have asked them to use the hygiene facilities and disinfectant measures available to them.

The Deputy asked that the Departments of Foreign Affairs and Tourism, Sport and Recreation be included in the task force. The task force met for the first time this morning and I will be pleased to convey the Deputy's recommendation that these Departments be included.

On the level of contact with the North, I have spoken on a number of occasions with the Minister, Bríd Rodgers, including today on the suspected case of the disease. The chief veterinary officer and his officials and the chief veterinary officer in the Department of Agriculture, Food and Rural Development in Dublin are in hourly contact with one another. The same applies to Mr. Scudamore in the UK. There is ongoing co-operation in relation to this crisis.
On the question of laboratory facilities, there are no testing facilities in this country. Testing is carried out in the UK and this does not cause a problem.

MainHeading.P: The Deputy asked if there is an adequate supply of detergent. My information is that there is an adequate supply of detergent. From the beginning, we were in touch with the suppliers and manufacturers of detergents to ensure they increased the supply because there is a huge demand for this. I am addressing all the issues raised by the Deputy.

Speaker.P: This issue is of great concern to everyone in the country. A number of the measures outlined are confined mainly to people who have been in contact with animals and involved in agriculture. How can urban dwellers prevent the spread of this disease? Given that approximately 80% of the population live in large towns and cities, what advice can the Minister give them in terms of their movement and behaviour during this crisis? Would the Minister advise people to restrict unnecessary journeys within the country and how will he communicate this message?

The Deputy is correct that this crisis affects every citizen in the country. Everyone has a duty to co-operate and be vigilant in regard to this potentially serious matter. Urban dwellers can help by not purchasing uncooked food of any kind such as dairy products and cheeses made from raw milk. There are a number of uncooked or partly cooked meats in which the virus survives. For example, it survives pasteurisation of milk. Any milk coming into the country – this would affect Border counties more than the south – should be double pasteurised or ultra high temperature treated. Urban dwellers should check cartons to ensure this is the case.
Should the product be on the shelves?

The first case was confirmed in the UK on Tuesday last week. The following day we issued a directive to all the retail outlets pointing out the susceptible products and asking that they not be stocked on shelves. Problems may arise where goods are delivered door to door.

I have asked people not to travel, especially to the UK, unless it is absolutely necessary. If they travel to Great Britain they should not visit farms because that will add to the risk. It will help if people take measures to reduce travelling and contact with farms and farm animals and not purchase uncooked or partly cooked products. People sometimes give crumbs to pet dogs. That is unhelpful and in the public notices we have included this as an activity to avoid . This is an extremely virulent organism. With the best will in the world we must take every possible precaution and this means trying to avoid even the most minimal of risks.

If the outbreak in Northern Ireland is confirmed will the Minister agree that County Donegal would be especially vulnerable due to the fact that the county has probably the longest land border with Northern Ireland? Can he guarantee that all crossings between County Donegal and other Border counties and Northern Ireland, either approved or unapproved, will be adequately manned to prevent the spread of the disease through either human or animal contact?
Will the Minister outline the latest measures taken along the Border? Has security been increased? What steps have been taken since this news broke at lunch time? What is being done?

Since lunch time we have been in discussions with the Garda and the Army to get their assistance in patrolling the Border roads. We have also enlisted additional resources and staff from my Department, for example, the land project officers and other officers. I have also contacted Teagasc. It has a good number of advisers who can be helpful in policing. The intention is to seal the Border as far as is possible.

With regard to the results of the test on this case, even though the exclusion zone includes a part of north County Louth that will not change the designation of Ireland as disease free. It will not affect our status on this disease.

In case anyone misinterpreted my comments yesterday, I confirm that meetings have taken place in Monaghan between the gardaí and the relevant authorities. The DVO and the personnel concerned are making every possible effort in very difficult circumstances. I understand it will be impossible to fully man all the minor Border crossings to ensure they remain closed. Will the Minister take account of the fact that personnel in some of the Border areas close to south County Armagh have asked that security measures be dramatically accelerated? Farm families are in dire fear of the total loss of their businesses. They have put it to me that it does not matter if things are brought to a standstill for a week, ten days or a fortnight.

Has the Minister considered the need to close roads if necessary? I hate the word “close” because we have lived with closed roads for too long, but we are dealing with a disastrous situation. Is proper lighting being provided, especially for the main checkpoints? There was a hit and run incident involving one garda and I understand a second was also injured. It has been drawn to my attention that some of the battery powered lamps are not very good, especially as the night goes on. We need to ensure that is properly addressed.

MainHeading.P: Will the Minister indicate how many Border roads are there? Deputy McGinley said the County Donegal stretch of the Border was perhaps the longest. The County Monaghan stretch might be slightly longer. The Border along the county is extremely difficult to man. Is the Minister satisfied that the roads are being manned in a satisfactory manner and that personnel on them are properly advised? From my inspection of some of the roads there are big differences between the ways in which some gardaí are carrying out their duties.
How many Army personnel are involved with the Garda? We have been told how many gardaí have been moved northwards.

Speaker.P: That might be a question for another Minister.

It is very relevant. A task force has been established to co-ordinate all the different groups concerned. When I travelled along the Border I did not see any Army involvement. I do not say it is not involved, but in a national emergency we must include everybody necessary. The Army could play no better role than to be present along the Border. Farm organisations, among others, have supplied water and addressed the other issues.

Have the different sport organisations in the Border area been contacted? I have contacted my county board chairman, Councillor Gary Carville, and he has advised me that discussions are ongoing with a view to cancelling the different games that are scheduled. It is essential this be done properly in the Border region.

Will the Minister ascertain if the Dundalk-Castleblayney road has been involved in the suspected outbreak? The road is causing serious problems. Last weekend people travelled to Dundalk and on their return they crossed the Border but could not return. A joint approach must be taken to addressing this aspect as it covers the most difficult area.

I do not know how much of the Border area the Minister has examined, but it is very complex. Has he any proof or otherwise that livestock has been moved illegally along these routes? Today I heard of a case in north County Monaghan where gates were left open and tracks were made at a time when the family concerned was in a hospital.
A question please, Deputy.

We need to ensure the Border area is contained by all the relevant personnel. I appreciate the Minister's comments on the involvement of Teagasc and Department officials. We need them all to be involved. In view of the situation the Fine Gael Party has cancelled its constituency convention in an effort to maintain the status quo in the area.

I appreciate the Deputy's acknowledgement of the role of the DVO and the gardaí in Monaghan. Department personnel, gardaí and everybody directly concerned have been working 17 or 18 hours a day to try and grapple with, and put measures in place to address a problem that was first confirmed in Great Britain a week ago yesterday. From Wednesday of last week, as matters have unfolded, every possible measure has been put in place.

MainHeading.P: The Garda are co-operating fully with the Department. As regards Border roads and unapproved roads, the Army has been at the Border for some days and if the Garda say additional Army personnel is required, the Army will provide whatever additional resources are necessary based on the Garda request. Sporting organisations have been totally co-operative and have been extremely helpful. They share everybody's concern about this disease.

The Deputy asked about illegal traffic in animals. There is an unfortunate situation here where a very small number of people flout the rules. Members will have seen in the media examples of where people have infected their own herds. People have been prosecuted for tampering with disease control regulations. In the Border area, there is some illicit traffic in animals. The investigation branch in the Department of Agriculture, Food and Rural Development, the Garda, the RUC and the authorities in the North of Ireland are working to stamp this out and to ensure, as far as is possible, that it is stamped out but, as the Deputy said, if gates are left open where a farm straddles the Border, it is extremely difficult. That is why everybody's co-operation is absolutely essential in this matter because unscrupulous people will find a loophole somewhere.

Speaker.P: On a point of information—
No, Deputy. I call Deputy Durkan.
The gates were not left open; they were opened by somebody when the family was away.

Whether or not we can contain the disease, given the suspected case in Northern Ireland, will the Minister now issue all bodies with an influence on the eventual outcome with ultimate instructions as if the outbreak was in this jurisdiction now so as to deal with a worst case scenario in the first instance and to recognise that whatever measures are taken now will be seen ultimately in terms of their effectiveness or otherwise?

The Minister mentioned that he has asked various bodies and agencies, both under the aegis of his Department and otherwise, not to proceed with visits or to go hill walking. Is it not time to issue specific instructions, because it will be too late in two or three days time?

MainHeading.P: This morning the Taoiseach mentioned the movement of animals to final destinations. Will the Minister look again at what that entails, because the movement of animals to final destinations can also have some serious consequences in certain circumstances? Will he look at those areas, in particular, and at the possibility of segregating the country into cells which can be isolated reasonably effectively? At least we might make a better attempt to control the outbreak than they did in the nearest jurisdiction.

On the question of encouraging people not to travel, I know some airlines and sea carriers have already indicated their willingness to compensate people in certain circumstances. I hope the Minister will use his influence and that of the Government to encourage carriers to do just that.

Speaker.P: Deputy Durkan asked if we would treat this suspect case as if it was a positive one. The decision taken this morning to prohibit the movement of all susceptible animals is such a response to that because that creates an exclusion zone within our own jurisdiction. The Taoiseach referred to a final destination this morning. A final destination is a slaughterhouse or an abattoir. People who have finished cattle and want them processed take them to a final destination and that will be allowed. We want to stop traffic of animals farm to farm and from one location to another. If farmers have finished animals and they want to take them to slaughter houses, that will be allowed.

The Deputy asked that various bodies be directed to cease various activities. We have called in a range of bodies and, in all cases, they have shared our concern and have called off the various events, gatherings and sporting activities. We will continue to do that if any suggestion is made here or elsewhere. I have no difficulty with people saying they have found a loophole or an access point because it should be investigated and attended to straight away. If a range of people are directed to do a particular job, some will do it better than others and some will know their job. I gave an instruction this morning that a standardised set of instructions be sent out to officers everywhere stating what they should do in particular circumstances to close off any small or minute risk and to seek to ensure the area is sealed as far as is humanly possible.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Brady Mr. J. Brady
Speaker.P: As regards visitors to historical places, I have been approached by those at Newgrange, Knowth and Dowth and the cairns outside Oldcastle where people trespass over land. What is the situation in that regard? Are the necessary measures being put in place to stop these people? Farmers in those areas are very concerned.

We spoke to Dúchas and asked it to close parks, various monuments and all the places people congregate and visit. In cases where people have to make a journey or where people have access to a farm, we have asked them to co-operate in minimising travel as much as is humanly possible. However, we need the total co-operation of the public in dealing with this matter.

Has the Minister received the full report on the lorry that brought the sheep from Carlisle to Armagh? Will he confirm that this lorry immediately travelled south to County Cavan? Will he state what type of load it was carrying? Will the Minister confirm that when apprehended in County Cavan, the driver gave false information about his destination? Has he satisfied himself as to where that lorry travelled in County Cavan? What precautions has he taken to ensure that the disease has not spread South of the Border given the activities of this driver and lorry on Thursday night of last week?

I made specific inquiries in the Department before I came in here to get the most up to date information available. The most up to date information on this driver is that inquiries are still being made and the driver is awaiting further questioning. In relation to the lorry driver and some activities North and South of the Border, it is extremely difficult to pinpoint and establish exactly where vehicles have been and to where they are going and we are doing this in conjunction with the RUC. At some times, the lorry or vehicle is north of the Border while at others, it is south of the Border. The Garda and our investigation branch are continuing their investigations intensively. I understand that at this point the driver is wanted for additional questioning.

There are 12 Deputies offering – Deputies Naughten, Farrelly, Connaughten, Timmins, Dukes, Upton, Joe Higgins, Sheehan, Perry, Ulick Burke, Deenihan and McGahon. I propose to take three questions and then a reply from the Minister. We will take a final question from Deputies Dukes and Penrose as the principal spokespersons. I call Deputies Naughten, Farrelly and Connaughton.

The Minister stated in his opening remarks that the farmer in County Armagh had been under suspicion for some time. For how long was he under suspicion and how long were the sheep on the farm? When was the Department of Agriculture, Food and Rural Development informed by the Department of Agriculture in Northern Ireland that this individual was under suspicion? Has the Department traced all of the sheep, pigs and cattle which were imported from the UK between 1 and 20 February? With the exception of the two cases in Wexford in which the animals are due to be slaughtered tomorrow, have all of those imported animals been destroyed? If they have been destroyed, were they slaughtered? What has happened to the carcases and by-products of these animals – have they also been destroyed or are they in circulation? What has happened to the sheep carcases and by-products of the incident in the west and what type of restrictions are currently in place there?

Will the task force consider cancelling St. Patrick's Day parades throughout Ireland as people from around the world travel here for this holiday and congregate in counties around the country? Why are there no disinfection mats at the doors of the Department of Agriculture, Food and Rural Development? I have just come from the Department and could not believe there were no mats; neither could the two farmers I met on the way out. Will the Minister instruct all local authorities, tax offices and other public buildings to provide disinfection mats? People go to tax offices throughout the country in droves at the end of the month to renew their car tax. I intend to contact all of the people for whom my business sells houses to ask them to provide disinfection mats at show houses next weekend and I call on the Minister to ask my colleagues throughout the country to do likewise. Last Saturday, hundreds of people from both urban and rural areas visited show houses in my area. We should curtail all public events. Two major events were due to take place the weekend after next in my constituency – our convention and a function to mark my 25 years in politics—

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Brady Mr. J. Brady
Speaker.P: I did not get a ticket.
—but we are in the process of cancelling them. Action must be taken everywhere people congregate.
I ask Deputies to confine their remarks to questions so that all Members may be facilitated.

Many of the questions I wished to ask have already been asked. Are there any potential flash points of foot and mouth disease in the Republic? Will the Minister confirm or deny that the Department has been called to a number of locations today in this regard? I do not have any proof that this has happened but I received a number of phone calls which suggested that there are some suspect areas. It is extremely important that we would be aware of any potential outbreaks.

I am not convinced that we can curtail the importation of sheep from the UK. We have never been able to do that. I have raised with the Minister on a number of occasions the question of sheep being illegally imported into this country in the dead of night. I am gravely concerned that numerous sheep may have been imported in the past two or three weeks about which nobody is aware.
The Deputy should put a question to the Minister.
I do not understand how the Department's control system could have clicked into gear in the past month when it has not been possible to control these imports in the past.

MainHeading.P: The Minister has stopped all on-farm inspections. As farmers do not have access to marts to sell their store cattle and sheep, will the Minister ensure all grants to farmers are paid promptly, irrespective of whether the farms have been inspected? Members of the agricultural community are hardest hit by this outbreak.

Speaker.P: Deputy Naughten asked about sheep which were imported into a plant in the west prior to the outbreak in the UK. Those sheep were slaughtered and departmental officials called to the plant where they interviewed everyone. Restrictions were imposed on any farms with which employees were associated as part-time farmers etc. and the farms will be kept under surveillance. The carcase by-products were rendered.
I congratulate Deputy Farrelly on his quarter of a century in public life and I wish him many more years as an elected representative.
I thank the Minister.

I have already asked people to avoid returning to Ireland to attend St. Patrick's Day parades. In the light of a number of suggestions and recommendations made here, I will undertake to ask parade organisers to cancel the parades as there is a risk, however small, where people congregate in large numbers. The cancellation of the parades will inconvenience and disappoint many people who have put great effort into their organisation but we must reduce risks, where possible.

A number of people have raised the issue of mats being placed at the entrances to public buildings, including Department buildings. Initially, we sought to ensure that mats and disinfectants were made available at access points to people who travelled to Ireland from abroad as this was the area of highest risk. However, I take the point that wherever people congregate, particularly those from an agricultural background, mats should be available and I will arrange for that to be done.

MainHeading.P: In reply to Deputy Connaughton, the Department has been called to a number of specific locations about which there were suspicions. I compliment members of the public on reporting strange or unusual happenings at farms, factories or abattoirs. We do not have reason to believe there is any suspicious case in the country at present. The Deputy's comments about sheep imports were also correct. It is amazing that although there are some eight million sheep in the country which do not command a great price – a fact for which I have received much of the blame – sheep continue to be imported. It has proved extremely difficult to control such imports. In my discussions with the social partners, I stated that these imports could be controlled only by tagging individual sheep. This was resisted by the major farming organisations. However, it will have to be done as there is no other way of controlling them. Since the importation ban was imposed, there have been no difficulties because all vehicles carrying sheep are sent back. There has not been a case since the ban was imposed, but it is those which emerged before it was imposed about which we are concerned.

The Deputy asked about on-farm visits which are cancelled and if grants are available. I will have inquire about those matters. Administratively, there is a need for accountability. In the case of some on-farm grants the works in question must be completed. I will look at what can be done. On premia and headage payments, a case can be made for paying 60% or 80% of the grant in advance and later reconciling—

Speaker.P: Some farmers have been left with no income.
I will inquire if advance payments can be made.
That happened a day or so after the ban was imposed. The ban was imposed last Wednesday after which it was placed under surveillance.

The Leas-Ceann Comhairle hit the kernel of the matter, inadvertently, when he interjected while Deputy Crawford was asking his question about the number of military personnel involved to state that the Deputy was addressing his question to the wrong Minister. While I appreciate that the Minister for Agriculture, Food and Rural Development is doing all he can, does he agree that the Government as a whole does not appreciate the extent of the problem? There should be several Ministers present. Let me give one simple example. The Minister called on Dúchas to curtail activity. In the national park in Wicklow, which stretches from Enniskerry to Tullow, a distance of 80 miles, there are approximately 1,000 wild goats and, at least, 8,000 wild deer, but up to yesterday it had not received any instructions. Has it been informed? The problem is that many Departments are not playing a role and will close the door only after the horse is gone. What does the Minister have to say about this?
Through the media.

Animals in the wild such as rats and hedgehogs are susceptible to foot and mouth disease. Has the Minister given any consideration to the procedures that could be put in place to restrict the movement of such animals? As the last outbreak of foot and mouth disease was in 1941, what training programmes have been put in place for vets and farmers? Is there an emergency update? As samples have to be sent to the United Kingdom, how long does it take to have a case confirmed?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Higgins (Dublin West) Mr. Higgins (Dublin West)
Speaker.P: (Dublin West) : It was suggested on the television programme, “Prime Time”, last night that up to 100 mares had been imported into Coolmore Stud from England following the outbreak of foot and mouth disease in England. Is this true and, if so, was the Department aware of it? Will the Minister give details to the Dáil? Why was that allowed to happen given that these animals pose as much of a risk as other animals which have been banned? Is it a question of Coolmore Stud being shown favouritism? Did the Government wait until last night before introducing the ban so as to allow animals to be imported? It has been reported in racing circles that if the Cheltenham racing festival takes place, the horse, Istabraq, will race. Given the incumbent risks this should be deplored by the Minister as it would encourage many to travel to Cheltenham. Will the Minister call on the horse's owner to declare that he will not travel?

I have sympathy for the Minister, a constituency colleague of mine, but we must be cruel to be kind. This is not a laughing matter. As well as deploying members of the Army and the Garda, the Government should mobilise members of Civil Defence to ensure all roads along the Border are monitored and kept under surveillance. Day-trippers to Holyhead must also be closely policed to ensure the necessary precautions are taken to prevent the spread of the disease. What steps are being taken to deal with the threat posed by letters and packages from Great Britain and Northern Ireland and the many trailers from the North which travel as far south as Bantry in the Minister's constituency approximately once a month at weekends? I was informed by two of the Minister's representatives last night at the Joint Committee on Agriculture, Food and the Marine that birds do not carry the disease. I learned this morning, however, that the French are concerned about seagulls. If that is so, we should be concerned about migratory birds which have flown here from England and Scotland because of the recent Arctic conditions, such as the lapwing, golden plover and green plover. What steps has the Department taken to tackle this problem?

What plans does the Minister have to extend the inspection of retail outlets by health board inspectors given that much of the stock available in the Republic is manufactured in Northern Ireland? Milk from Northern Ireland is on sale in Sligo today. Is the Minister aware that a huge number of employees, particularly in the construction industry, cross the Border? Has he consulted the builders' federation on the importance of this matter? Is he also aware that the message can be got accross simply and effectively on local radio and in the local press? Much time has been lost as a result. Are retail stores being inspected to ensure stock is not on sale? Although instructions have been issued, has the Minister consulted RGDATA which represents retail grocers on this important matter?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. U. Burke Mr. U. Burke
Speaker.P: What is the position with regard to veterinary practitioners who up to very recently, were carrying out herd tests? Are departmental veterinary practitioners still doing tests on herds throughout the country? It is important that such work should cease as a matter of urgency, if it has not already ceased.

In the event of cattle being moved from farms to factories for slaughter, what is the situation as regards requirements? Can on-farm REPS inspections be postponed and payments given in trust until retrospective inspections are done? Many people depend on these payments because of the crisis in farming of recent years, so it is important that payments are made in trust until things get back to normal. Where has the offal from sheep who have been slaughtered been rendered?

Deputy Timmins urged a greater degree of co-ordination between different Departments and different agencies, but we have 100% co-operation at the moment. Many Deputies have called for additional representation on the task force that has been set up, and we will take that into account and make sure it happens. We are arranging for advertisements during the next couple of days, to heighten the awareness of the general public and retailers in the street.

Deputy Dukes referred to last week's advertisements as being turgid and technical. We will have them in layman's language as far as that is possible this week, and try to arrange to have them on the front page. Deputy Upton spoke of the need to reduce the risk from rats and hedgehogs on farms and I will talk to veterinary experts in my Department when I return. It must be remembered that while we want to minimise risk, we have not had any confirmed cases in the country yet. We want to do everything possible to keep foot and mouth disease out.

Deputy Joe Higgins asked about mares coming into the country, as this is the breeding season. As the disease spread in the United Kingdom during the past week, we issued a directive banning all non-susceptible animals, including horses, from coming in to Ireland. No horses have come here since that directive was issued a couple of days ago. No favouritism or selectivity was used, as a number of stud farms receive mares from outside the country. The National Stud takes 60% to 65% of its mares from abroad.

I do not have an ante-post bet on Istabraq, and I hope many more people do not either. I strongly urge all horse owners, who have put in a great deal of preparation, not to go to Cheltenham or to send their horses. That particularly includes Istabraq. This will be disappointing and inconvenient for everybody. Istabraq has a huge following in Ireland, and many people might go to Cheltenham because he might run there. If the event at Cheltenham takes place, I publicly call on the trainer and owner of Istabraq not to send him there.

MainHeading.P: Deputy Sheehan spoke of enlisting the civil defence, which is a good suggestion, and I will take that up. He also spoke of traders, including those in west Cork in Castletownbere and Bantry. There is still a fair at Bantry, although I do not think there is an animal from one end of the square to the other. However, traders still come many of whom come from as far away as Scotland and the North. They are subject to the same regulations as everybody else, including certification of disinfection. There are not usually any live animals there, and hardware of various kinds and non-food items are sold.
Deputy Sheehan is probably one of the world's greatest authorities on seagulls.

Speaker.P: If they had votes I would get about ten quotas.
The Mizen Head seagull is a renowned species. Birds can transmit this disease, and travel long distances, so the matter is being kept under review.

Deputy Perry asked who was monitoring food in retail outlets. The Food Safety Authority of Ireland is responsible for this. RGDATA and various retail outlets have been directly contacted by the Department.

As far as possible, I have availed of local radio and local media throughout the country. I have particularly tried to do this in Border counties where the problem is concentrated. It is a good medium of communication. REPS inspections have been stopped, but I will look at regulations, accountability and Irish and EU audit requirements to see if advance payments can be made. I hope this problem will not last too long, but if it does I will try to help farmers as they have to survive, and they have been through enough difficulties already.

Does the Minister have contingency plans to burn carcases in the awful event of an outbreak here? Has he given any consideration to a nation wide television campaign to heighten awareness even further? Have arrangements been made regarding the disinfection of shoes at religious ceremonies this weekend? Does the Minister think non-essential meetings should be called off? Has he considered mobilising the FCA?

Is the Minister aware that the Crufts dog show will take place in England this weekend? What advice would he give to breeders who have arranged to travel there? Will they be allowed to take their dogs and more importantly, if they go, will they be allowed to bring them back into the country?

Have we banned the cross-Border movement of cattle feeds like hay, silage and cereal products? There is a great deal of agricultural traffic at this time of year involved in sowing grain and in ploughing. Can this be strictly monitored? I am concerned that products would be moved across the Border without proper checks.
There is not much sowing in Border areas at the moment.

If this problem continues for some time, would it be appropriate to have an information leaflet distributed to every household? The last outbreak was in 1941, so not many people would remember it. It is important to inform the public why restrictions are being put in place, and why large gatherings of people are being discouraged. Is there a penalty for those who knowingly or wittingly import animals on to their lands from across the Border? Could grants, headage payments or REPS payments be revoked if people are found guilty of such an offence?

Most Deputies agree with the ban on public events. Living as I do three miles from the border with Armagh, I can tell the Minister that, because of the strength of sterling, the biggest danger is posed by thousands of people who come from the North to shop in Dundalk, Drogheda and other towns along the Border and the thousands of young people who attend discos and hotels over the weekend. Will this movement be stopped as it poses a big danger? Has the Minister recruited extra veterinary surgeons and, if so, are they deployed in the Border area? Will the Minister put many punters out of their misery by making an early decision on the Cheltenham racing festival? J. P. McManus does not have to be told about the national interest; his commitment to Ireland has been well demonstrated.

(Wexford) : Given that his Department has this afternoon ordered the slaughtering of 1,300 sheep imported from Devon and rumours and innuendoes are sweeping the county, will the Minister make a statement clarifying the position in County Wexford? Can he account for the traceability of the sheep in question? Have they all been rounded up? Have they been in contact with sheep in the locality? Local people are of the view that there should be an Army presence at Rosslare Port to support the Garda and the Revenue Commissioners.

I support what Deputy Browne said about the situation in County Wexford, which is a cause of concern. People have become aware of this information, not only in County Wexford but elsewhere in the south east. The Minister should make a statement as soon as possible to clear up the matter. I appreciate that he has a difficult job to do, but farmers are worried. There is no room for a casual approach to the matter. It is clear that there was no emergency plan in place to deal with an outbreak of foot and mouth disease as farmers were unable to obtain disinfectant in many of the branches of Glanbia in County Kilkenny in order to adhere to the regulations laid down by the Minister.

I was worried when I heard the Minister say that he had known for one week that a farm in County Armagh was under suspicion. It took him one week to introduce restrictions. I do not know if there are restrictions in place in the rendering plant at which the animals in question were destroyed. That kind of statement does not engender confidence among producers and consumers about the manner in which the issue is being dealt. In spite of the difficult job the Minister has, I ask him to redouble his efforts and those of his staff and to take whatever action is necessary at ports and elsewhere to ensure these issues are dealt with.

The fact that there are rumours in County Wexford about the sheep imported from Devon is a clear indication that many are worried about this issue. The rumour that 1,300 sheep will be slaughtered has probably led everybody to believe that there is an outbreak of foot and mouth disease in County Wexford. That is the reason it is important to give the public the correct information as soon as possible.

The Minister is wrong to adopt a voluntary code of practice calling on people's goodwill not to travel to Cheltenham. In view of the scale of the crisis, that is not good enough. People must be forced to make decisions by the Department in the national interest.

Based on local knowledge and contact with my office in County Louth today I understand, given the proximity of the farm in Meigh, approximately four kilometres north of the Border, it is intended to establish an exclusion zone extending across the Border.
